A bad month for “Fix the Debt” was a good month for the American economy.

Check out Mary Bottari’s article for PRWatch entitled, “Fix the Debt’s Last Harrumph.”

This week, the White House announced that the Social Security cutting Chained CPI will not be included in the president’s annual budget. Last week, Congress voted to raise the government’s borrowing limit, avoiding the hostage taking tactics used last year by House Republicans.

Nearly two years after Wall Street billionaire Pete Peterson founded “Fix the Debt,” his hostage taking strategies and attempts to cut earned benefits have failed. His organization reportedly spent at least $43 million attempting to advance their disastrous policies. Policies which could have added as much as $173 billion to the coffers of his Wall Street and big business buddies. 

The American people have spoken. Don’t cut earned benefits!  Don’t balance the budget on the backs of the most vulnerable members of our society: the elderly, the children, the sick and the poor.

Increasing wealth and income inequality in the United States has become the great moral and economic issue of our time. There are ways to solve this problem, and it begins by acknowledging that the current federal minimum wage of $7.25 an hour is a starvation wage.

Join U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders and Democracy for America in calling on Congress to increase the federal minimum wage to $10.10 an hour.

In a recent letter to President Obama, 16 Senators, including U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders who authored the letter, told the president not to include cuts to Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid in his annual budget.

The Senators wrote, “Mr. President: These are tough times for our country.  With the middle class struggling and more people living in poverty than ever before, we urge you not to propose cuts in your budget to Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid benefits – cuts which would make life even more difficult for some of the most vulnerable people in America.”

In a recent interview, Sanders said, "The focus of attention right now has got to be on the collapsing middle class. What we need from the president now is a reassurance that he is not going to cut Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid."

There are many important issues that Bernie will be working on in 2014, but in order to be successful, we must rally the American people behind our shared ideals of addressing wealth and income inequality, creating millions of good paying jobs, raising the minimum wage to a living wage, overturning the disastrous Citizens United Supreme Court decision, addressing the climate crisis, and much more.

In a year full of distressing stories — especially about race, crime and violence in urban neighborhoods — this one points to some hope. Earlier this December, we covered a summer jobs program in Chicago that appeared to lead to fewer teenage arrests for violent crime. Our original story, republished below, also reminds us that policy solutions are possible — and possibly even inexpensive.

A couple of years ago, the city of Chicago started a summer jobs programfor teenagers attending high schools in some of the city's high-crime, low-income neighborhoods. The program was meant, of course, to connect students to work. But officials also hoped that it might curb the kinds of problems — like higher crime — that arise when there's no work to be found.

Research on the program conducted by the University of Chicago Crime Lab and just published in the journal Science suggests that these summer jobs have actually had such an effect: Students who were randomly assigned to participate in the program had 43 percent fewer violent-crime arrests over 16 months, compared to students in a control group.

That number is striking for a couple of reasons: It implies that a relatively short (and inexpensive) intervention like an eight-week summer jobs program can have a lasting effect on teenage behavior. And it lends empirical support to a popular refrain by advocates: "Nothing stops a bullet like a job."

The Richer You Are the Older You’ll Get - Josh Zumbrun, The Wall Street Journal: 

Money may not buy love, but it appears to buy years.

Economist Barry Bosworth at the Brookings Institution crunched the numbers and found that the richer you are, the longer you’ll live. And it’s a gap that is widening, particularly among women.

Mr. Bosworth parsed this data from the University of Michigan’s Health and Retirement Study, a survey that tracks the health and work-life of 26,000 Americans as they age and retire. The data is especially valuable as it tracks the same individuals every two years in what’s known as a longitudinal study, to see how their lives unfold.

The good news is that men of all incomes are living longer. Yet the data shows that the life expectancy of the wealthy is growing much faster than the life expectancy of the poor.
